summary: This is a government filing opposing Jeffrey Epstein's motion for pretrial release, arguing he is a flight risk and danger to the community. It details his vast wealth, history of witness manipulation, and the discovery of nude photos of young females in his home. The government asserts the bail proposal is inadequate and requests detention pending trial. This is a government memorandum filed by the U.S. Attorney's Office opposing Jeffrey Epstein's motion for bail release. It argues Epstein is a severe flight risk and danger to the community, detailing his vast wealth, past obstruction of justice, and the inadequacy of proposed private security and electronic monitoring. It also previews legal arguments regarding the scope of a prior non-prosecution agreement. This is a government letter filed in advance of Jeffrey Epstein's bail hearing on July 8, 2019, arguing for his pretrial detention. It details the charges of sex trafficking of minors, the strength of the evidence, Epstein's extreme wealth and flight risk, his prior Florida investigation and non-prosecution agreement, and concerns about witness intimidation. This is a government memorandum in support of pretrial detention for Jeffrey Epstein, filed in July 2019. It argues he is a severe flight risk and danger to the community, detailing his vast wealth, international travel, prior conviction, and alleged witness tampering. It includes attached police reports documenting witness intimidation incidents from 2006.

events.title: Detention Hearing before Magistrate Judge Pitman

events.title: Search of Epstein's Manhattan Mansion
events.description: Law enforcement executed search warrants at Epstein's New York residence, discovering hundreds or thousands of nude/seminude photos of young females.

events.title: Unsealing of Indictment and New Victim Reports
events.description: Following the unsealing of the indictment, several additional women in multiple jurisdictions came forward identifying themselves as victims from when they were minors.

events.title: Epstein's Prior Conviction and NPA
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted of a state sex crime involving a minor and entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Miami Herald Article Series Publication
events.description: The Miami Herald began publishing a series of articles about Epstein, his conduct, and the circumstances of his prior conviction and NPA.

events.title: $100,000 Wire Transfer
events.description: Epstein wired $100,000 from a trust account to an individual named as a possible co-conspirator in the NPA, two days after the Miami Herald series began.

events.title: $250,000 Wire Transfer
events.description: Epstein wired $250,000 from the same trust account to another individual named as a possible co-conspirator and identified as his employee in the indictment.

events.title: Bail Hearing Arguments
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files this memorandum opposing Epstein's release on bail, arguing he is a flight risk and danger to the community.

events.title: Federal Indictment Returned
events.description: A federal grand jury in the Southern District of New York returned a sealed indictment charging Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy.

events.title: Bail Hearing Scheduled
events.description: The bail hearing for Jeffrey Epstein is scheduled, prompting this government letter arguing for pretrial detention.

events.title: Prior Florida Investigation Begins
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was investigated by local police in Palm Beach, Florida, for similar sex offenses against minor girls, later involving federal authorities.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida regarding the Palm Beach investigation.

events.title: State Court Guilty Plea
events.description: Epstein pled guilty in Florida state court to one count of procuring a person under 18 for prostitution and one count of solicitation of prostitution, becoming a registered sex offender.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty in Florida state court to one count of procuring a person under the age of 18 for prostitution.

events.title: Arrest and Search of NY Mansion
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport. Law enforcement searched his New York mansion pursuant to warrants, discovering lewd photographs and evidence consistent with victim accounts.

events.title: Witness Intimidation Incident
events.description: A victim's father was aggressively followed and forced off the road by a private investigator allegedly working for Epstein. Phone records show calls between a victim, an Epstein associate, and Epstein's corporate office around the time of the incident.

events.title: Witness Tampering Attempt
events.description: A victim was approached during Spring Break 2006 and offered monetary compensation to not cooperate with law enforcement, with a threat that "those who hurt him will be dealt with."

events.description: The government filed this memorandum arguing for Epstein's pretrial detention, citing flight risk and danger to the community.

keyFacts: The government states Jeffrey Epstein is worth over $500 million according to financial records from 'Institution-1' and earns at least $10 million per year.
Hundreds or thousands of nude and seminude photographs of young females were discovered in Epstein's Manhattan mansion during a search following his arrest.
Epstein's proposed bail package includes his Manhattan mansion (already subject to forfeiture) and private jet as collateral, which the government argues is worthless and inadequate.
The indictment alleges Epstein sexually exploited dozens of minors, including girls as young as 14, in New York and Florida, and that he paid victims to recruit other underage girls.
Multiple victims and their attorneys have contacted the government requesting Epstein's detention, expressing fear for their safety if he is released.
The government alleges Epstein attempted to obstruct justice by wiring $350,000 to two possible co-conspirators in late 2018, shortly after the Miami Herald published exposés on his case.
The document references past witness intimidation, including a private investigator driving a victim's parent off the road and an associate offering to buy victims' silence.
The government argues Epstein's proposal for bail with private, armed security paid by him is legally dubious, creates a conflict of interest, and fosters inequity based on wealth.
The government contends the 2008 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with the Southern District of Florida does not bar prosecution in New York for conduct that occurred there.
Evidence cited includes the discovery in Epstein's mansion of discs with labels like 'Young [Name] + [Name]' and 'Girl pics nude' containing photographs of underage females.
The government argues Jeffrey Epstein is a severe flight risk due to his extraordinary wealth, ownership of private jets, international ties, and faces a potential 45-year prison sentence.
Epstein is accused of a years-long scheme to sexually abuse dozens of minor girls, some as young as 14, in New York and Florida, using a network of victim-recruiters.
A search of Epstein's New York residence upon his arrest yielded an 'extraordinary volume of photographs of nude and partially-nude young women or girls.'
The government asserts the 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the Southern District of Florida does not bind the Southern District of New York and does not cover victims outside Florida.
The letter cites legal precedent that 18 U.S.C. § 1591 (sex trafficking) applies to both suppliers and consumers of commercial sex acts with minors.

The government argues Epstein is an extreme flight risk due to his vast wealth (including a $77M NY mansion, $12M FL estate, private island, 15 vehicles, and two private jets), lack of family ties, and frequent international travel.
Epstein was a registered Level 3 sex offender in New York, classified as a "high" risk to re-offend, stemming from his 2008 Florida conviction.

During the 2019 search of Epstein's NY mansion, law enforcement found hundreds to thousands of sexually suggestive photographs of nude or partially-nude females, some appearing to be underage, including in a locked safe.
The document references credible past allegations of witness tampering and obstruction by Epstein, including an incident where his private investigator forced a victim's father off the road in 2006.
Attached police reports from 2006 detail attempts to intimidate victims and their families, including offers of monetary compensation for non-cooperation and aggressive surveillance.
